as I received your email, I was, non-creatively, watching the NASA EDGE, Hawaii webcam and the Space Station and their flickr feed. I had a really swell time doing so, listening to all the history and chitter-chat, just feeding off on the excitement of all those involved.

The transit was awesome :) I'm so glad that i had a chance to see it one and only time in my life.  I projected the view through binoculars onto piece of paper :) And I was amazed that you can even see sunspots by using this method! :)
through a welding hood =D cuz ima welder!!

I drove from Enschede (you've been there right? =D) to the Baltic sea near Kiel, Germany. We watched the sun rise out of the sea and looked H-Alpha solar telescopes and normal telescopes, binoculars and 200mm camera lenses (I shot with my old but good Canon A-1) with filters filtering out 99.999%.of the light. It was pretty amazing, and we were very lucky. Where we were was pretty much the closest place that wasn't clouded over. Absolutely amazing experience, once in a life-time (I missed 2004).
It was all stormy in Wellington, New Zealand... Couldn'tve seen if I tried, guess I'll just wait another 105 odd years

acceleration due to gravity (mg) until the air resistance (-bv) cancels out further acceleration, resulting in terminal velocity.
Said terminal velocity can be greater or less(er?) depending on mass of the object and it's aerodynamics.  For example, a rock will fall much faster than a piece of paper.  
Maneuvering is accomplished by changing the direction of which air hits your body much like the surface of an airplane wing.
Parachute is deployed, causing a drastic reduction in velocity.

I watched the transit from a local park over here by Winnipeg. There was a planned out star party in a certain area an I could not have believed the amount of publicity it got. As a rough estimate, I would say there were about 1500 unique people who came by, left or stayed at the star party. We also had an impressive amount of telescopes ranging from binoculars with impromptu filters to a really old fashioned telescope brought by an old man.It was fun and I even got to meet a lot of astronomers.

I am watching Venus, watching it with my 150-500mm Sigma lens on my Nikon Camera with a glass from welding mask taped to the end of the lens. I agree too, it's not important. But how boring would life be if we only did things because they were important?
Fictional books wouldn't exist because reading them wouldn't really educate people (though on the plus side, no Twilight); no films would ever be made (though again, no Twilight) and phones would never go beyond those big old bricks we used in the '90s.
Importance isn't the only thing that makes things worth doing.
P.S. Apologies if you happen to be a Twilight fan.

Several factors.  At first; it was used to estimate the size of the sun, the distance of the earth from the sun, as well as the general size of the Solar System.  Now, it is used in the same manner of finding exoplanets in other Stellar Systems.  We can see the light intensity fade as Venus and Mercury transit in front of the sun, which allows us to take the recordings we discover and use the same principle to discover external bodies.

I remember watching eclipses through optical media: cd's or dvd's. The thin metal foil inside is almost opaque but strong light sources is visible through. Don't know whether it's eye safe though.
